Pros: Easier cleaning process.
Cons: Exclude georeferenciable records by locality information that could be repaired.

Pros: Reduce time of manipulation.
Cons: Some ‘coordinates issues’ are too strict (e.g. 'assign datum WGS84').

Pros: Need basic geographical check and validation.

Process: Only records with coordinates filtered by spatial extent (area or administrative units)
Pros: Depending on the selected area can exclude unreliable records (e.g. zero coordinates, sea points, etc.)
Cons: Exclude records from suitable/native regions not considered by bibliography.

Pros: Exclude records from introduced distribution areas.
Cons: Exclude georeferenciable records by locality information that could be repaired.

Pros: Less time of manipulation than download all available records with coordinates.
More information available including records labelled as 'with coordinates issues'.
More information available including records labelled as 'with coordinates issues' and records with geographical information that can be repaired (e.g. zero coordinates, sea points, etc.)
Cons: Check and validation processes are needed due to coordinates issues.

Pros: Less time of processing than download all available records with no filters.
Cons: Exclude georeferenciable records by locality information that could be repaired.
May include records of introduced areas.

Pros: Include all the available information.
Cons: Needs an exhaustive process of filtering, cleaning and repairing the data.

Pros: Records without coordinates but locality information can be retrieved and repaired.
Cons: Larger time of manipulation.

Process: 1. Check and filter based on coordinates precision. Choose and option:
Pros: Led to filter records with the highest precision on geographical position.
Cons: This information is usually not included.

Pros: Better solution to consider coordinates precision when this information is not provided.
Cons: Increase time of manipulation.

Pros: Keep same criteria to filter records avoiding errors in field of coordinates precision.
Discard records with low geographical precision and potential location errors.
Less restrictive.
Cons: Increase geographical uncertainty.

Pros: Increase number of records when a few are available.
Cons: Include records far from original location.

Process: 2.Check coordinates value and do not validate records if any of these conditions are true.
Pros: Exclude unreliable records
Cons: Reduce available information that can be repaired manually using locality information.

Pros: Label records and correct manually coordinates using locality information.
Cons: Include unreliable records

Process: a. Are coordinates placed in correct habitat (sea / land)?
Pros: Exclude unreliable records.
Cons: Reduce available information that can be repaired manually using locality information.

Pros: Label records placed out of their habitat and calculate distance from coastline.
Correct coordinates values placed nearby the country assigned at certain distance. (Use ‘plantR::checkShore’)

Process: b. Are coordinates placed in the country assigned?
Pros: Identify location errors due to signs of coordinates.
Cons: Misidentification of country names due to errors of collector input.

Pros: Exclude unreliable records.
Cons: Records located nearby country borders and low precision can be deleted.

Process: c. Check position of records that are not placed in the country assigned.
Pros: Identify location errors due to signs of coordinates.
Cons: Increase time of manipulation.

Pros: Identify records located nearby country borders.

Process: d. Check records placed in prime meridian or equator countries
Pros: Identify location errors at a finer resolution due to signs errors in coordinates.
Cons: Increase time of manipulation.
Needs regional name string information to match names.

Process: e. Delete or label as potential errors those records whose coordinates are centroids of:
Pros: Identify potential error of location.
Cons: Reduce available information that can be repaired manually using locality information.

Pros: Help to discard records with geographical uncertainty.
Cons: Increase time of manipulation.

Pros: Detect locality or province centroids may be a highly strict filter, recommended in regional local studies.
Exclude records from places that contains captured/cultivated specimens and wrong references to GBIF institution.
Increase number of records when a few are available.
Cons: Include unreliable records increasing geographical uncertainty.

Process: a. Retrieve coordinates indicated in other formats from other fields as locality information.
Pros: Increase number of records when a few are available.
Cons: Increase time of manipulation.

Pros: Feasible with small datasets.
Cons: Semi-automatic/manual check through dataset to find degrees’ information.
Not recommended for large datasets.

Process: b.  Use locality information or position description to generate coordinates.
Pros: Increase number of records when a few are available.
Cons: Increase time of manipulation.

Pros: Feasible with small datasets.
Cons: Locality centroids present low precision generating uncertainty.

Pros: Useful for studies that analyse higher administrative units than those used to retrieve centroids.
Cons: Locality names are not standardized and can be written in multiple languages to translate.
Mismatch of localities with same name in different locations leading into misidentification of coordinates.
Do not apply if records with coordinates placed in centroids were deleted in step 3.
Not recommended for large datasets.

Process: c. Do not correct coordinate values
Pros: Avoid assign centroids or coordinates low precise that add uncertainty.
Cons: Discard multiple records when a few are available.

Process: Are coordinates placed in the species native range / extent of presence?
Pros: Identify and exclude species misidentifications.
Cons: Exclude records due to incorrect maps, natural changes in geographic distribution or introduced areas.

Pros: Keep only records located in the native region of the species.
Cons: May be too restrictive.
Increase time of manipulation.
Administrative unit names can change through time.

Process: Does country name match with their native region?
Pros: Identify and exclude species misidentifications.
Cons: Exclude records due to incorrect maps, natural changes in geographic distribution or introduced areas.

Pros: Keep only records located in the native region of the species.
Cons: May be too restrictive.
Increase time of manipulation.
Administrative unit names can change through time.

Process: Do not use distributional info for filter
Pros: Less restrictive.
Cons: Include misidentifications.

Pros: Keep records located out of the native region of the species.
Include information of new locations not referenced in bibliography.

Process: a) Calculate environmental centroids for the species and validate outliers.
Pros: Helps identifying and excluding species misidentifications.
Cons: May be too restrictive.
Increase time of manipulation.
Needs high detailed environmental information to establish threshold.

Process: b. Calculate environmental space for species and check overlaps and delete outliers.
Pros: Helps identifying and excluding species misidentifications.
Cons: May be too restrictive.
Increase time of manipulation.
Needs high detailed environmental information to establish threshold.

Process: c. Overlap environmental information by geographical position and filter occurrences by threshold.
Pros: Helps identifying and excluding species misidentifications.
Cons: May be too restrictive.
Increase time of manipulation.
Needs high detailed environmental information to establish threshold.

Process: d. Do not apply a filter for environmental outliers
Pros: Less restrictive.
Cons: Dataset may include misidentifications.

Pros: Include information of new locations not referenced in bibliography.

Process: Don't filter by Basis of Record
Pros: Include machine observations, literature records, material sample or unknown basis of records.
Cons: Include fossil species.

Pros: Keep all the available information for afterwards filters.
Cons: Records with an unknown nature of collection are less reliable.
Needs more filter/clean processing, increasing time of manipulation.

Pros: Allow material revision for correct and update taxonomic identification [2][5]
Cons: May include coordinates of museums, institutions, etc. instead of the real coordinates of collection [1] or administrative units [5]

Pros: Include rarer species than observations [2]
Cons: They are usually older than observations with more unreliability associated to them [2][3]

Pros: High reliable records usually collected by experts and researchers [5].
Cons: Associated to small sample sizes [2]

Pros: Associated to recent data [2][3]
Cons: Less reliable for misidentifications [5] due to collection from amateurs.

Pros: Higher number of records available [2][3]
Cons: They usually correspond to common species [2] and easily to observe and identify taxa [4]

Pros: Wider geographical range [2]
Cons: May include records outside of their species range (invasive, domestic, horticultural or introduced species) [2]

Pros: More geographical precision (usually take with GPS) [5].
Cons: Biased toward human areas [3][4]

Pros: Combination of data types increase temporal, spatial, taxonomical and environmental coverage [2]
Cons: May include records outside of their species range (invasive, domestic, horticultural or introduced species) [2]
May include coordinates of museums, institutions, etc. instead of the real coordinates of collection [1] or administrative units [5] .

Pros: Consider coordinates precision.
Cons: Delete false duplicates.

Pros: Useful for species distribution models.
Consider coordinates precision.
Cons: Delete false duplicates.

Pros: Useful for aggregated records in oversampled areas.
Minimum information usually available.
Cons: Do not consider coordinates precision.
Errors detecting real duplicates when multiple vouchers of the same specimen were georeferenced using different methods.

Pros: More precise than using only year of collection.
Cons: Omitting information of records without temporal information.

Pros: Accept other combination using information of month and year of collection (MM/YYYY) [7]
Year description appears more often than complete date.
Cons: Delete occurrences recorded the same year but not in the same sample moment.

Pros: Use when there are a few records available and they lack date of collection.
Cons: Errors detecting real duplicates.

Pros: Consider recorder name is highly strict but precise detecting duplicates.
Cons: Collector's name is usually not indicated.
The field is not standardized [7]
Include different types of collectors and quality associated to identification: taxonomists > experts > amateurs [20]

Pros: Highest precision of record’s temporal coverage.
Cons: Many records are not linked with the day and/or month of collection.

Pros: Help to detect duplicate records by complete date of collection.
Cons: Format date can include DD/MM or MM/DD generating unreliable information.

Pros: Allow seasonal-temporal analyses of records.

Process: b. At least year of collection
Pros: Help to detect duplicate records by year of collection.
Cons: Limited information for taxa with few records available.

Pros: Avoid old records (less reliable and lower uncertainty) [5, 6] and/or current year with lag of information.
Cons: Discard large proportion of records due to absence in year of collection. [7]
Duplicate records based only on the year of collection led to discard different sample events from the same year.

Pros: Allow to filter and adjust pool of records to other variables (e.g. climate) [5] representing the same temporal range and then more realistic results [6]
Cons: Particular temporal ranges can be affected by biases between record types [2]
Can generate bias between regions due to different temporal coverage of samples of the areas [7, 8].
Exclude some useful information (out of the temporal range) for geographical and taxonomical analysis.

Pros: Include the longest temporal coverage of data that it is useful in studies of changes over time [6].
Cons: Include old data that are less reliable and have more uncertainty [5, 8] and current year with lag of information.
Older data present lower quality due to changes in ecological, demographic or dispersal processes and taxonomic changes or status [6, 8]
Older data loss information content of the record [6]
Older records lack location precision [5] and could use outdated methodologies [6]
Make unrealistic comparisons of presence records and environmental information that did not coexist in time generating commission errors  [6]

Pros: Have all the information available to filter afterwards.
Cons: Needs more filter/clean processing, increasing time of manipulation.

Pros: Can retrieve temporal information from metadata of datasets.
Cons: Duplicate records are difficult to detect without date information.
May include illegitimate dates [17] (e.g. before 1600 or after current year).
Older data present less quality due to changes in ecological, demographic or dispersal processes and taxonomic changes or status [6]
Older data lose information content of the record [6]
Older records lack location precision [5] and could use outdated methodologies [6]
Make unrealistic comparisons of presence records and environmental information that did not coexist in time generating commission errors  [6]

Process: Download all records from higher taxonomic level
Pros: Have all the information available to make multiple filters afterwards.
Cons: Clean and filter process is needed afterwards due to records without proper taxonomical rank.
Increase time of manipulation.

Process: Create a list of species (accepted names and synonyms) from previous taxonomical knowledge and query databases.
Pros: Avoid records without proper taxonomic rank.
Cons: Mismatch between taxonomic checklist concepts choose and taxonomical source used in records’ database can led to partial/erroneous downloads.

Pros: Helps to query different databases with the same standardized names considering the synonyms and variations.
Cons: Needs reliable sources of taxonomical information to include all taxa (accepted names and synonyms).

Pros: Include authorship name to avoid mismatches of scientific names from different taxa with the same name.
For small dataset.
Cons: Increase processing time.

Pros: Supervised outputs.
For large datasets.
Cons: Increase errors associated to unsupervised outputs.

Pros: Reduce processing time.
Appropriate for large scale studies with multiple regions included.
Cons: Limited information when regional taxonomic concepts have conflicts.

Pros: Appropriate for regional studies.
Cons: No information published from certain regions.

Pros: Use in multi-taxa studies.
Cons: Mismatches of scientific names from different taxa with the same name.

Pros: Use when specific checklists are not available.
Use in studies of specific taxa.
Cons: May not have an automated tool available for certain taxa.

Pros: Correct checklists typos.
Cons: Led to misidentification of taxa with similar names (even in different parts of the tree of life) [12].

Pros: Include scientific names with spelling variations based on different sources.
Cons: Different outputs depending on score value.

Pros: Avoid misidentification due to typos or misspellings of scientific names.
Cons: May decrease number of records due to differences in scientific names.

Process: Is the record identified at a proper taxonomic rank?
Pros: Helps identifying reliable information.
Cons: Discard scientific names of higher taxonomic ranks reduce available information.

Pros: If higher, discard scientific names due to uncertainty on identification.
Cons: May lead to misidentifications due to conflicts between varieties, subspecies, forms or hybrids when merge into the next higher rank.

Pros: If lower, merge scientific name into the next higher rank simplifies the taxonomic checklist.

Process: Does the scientific name have authorship information?
Pros: Helps identifying potential misidentifications.
Cons: Discard scientific names that does not have authorship information reduce available information.
Potential misidentification if this filter is not applied.
Increase time of processing.
Authorship names can be spelling differently, so manually checks are needed.

Pros: Accepted (pros):
Cons: Accepted (cons):

Pros: Reliable information.
Cons: Some records do not include authorship information which increase the uncertainty to confirm taxonomical status.
Potential misidentification if authorship names differ between input names and accepted ones.

Pros: Synonym (pros):
Cons: Synonym (cons):

Pros: Correct outdated scientific names.
Cons: Change information from original source.

Pros: Harmonize taxa for interspecific studies.
Cons: Potential misidentifications due to regional differences in identification.

Pros: Unresolved (pros):
Cons: Unresolved (cons):

Pros: Manual corrections afterwards to include information.
Cons: Potential misidentifications.

Pros: Metadata revision to find taxonomic errors.
